Even Boyle thought that the atoms cohere by reason oi their jagged shapes. The three agreed, however, in looking to the power oi God as final cause in the building up oi things out oi atoms. With the discovery oi the law of gravitation the course of physical speculation was changed. Gradually the doctrine of attraction and repulsion‚ the conception oi forces acting im- mediately in the relations of atoms one with another, was intro- duced. The new principle seemed so potent and wide-reaching in its application, that an all-moving spirit hardly seemed neces· sary in accounting ior the on·going oi the universe. A tendency to the mechanical explanation ol nature became manifest. ln accordance with the spirit oi this, Locke formulated his doctrine of sensationalism, which so harmonized with the trend of the times that it was most widely adopted as embodying the true theory oi knowledge. The uniolding and application ol its doc· trines revolutionized European speculatioo, leading directly to the F rerich “ illumination,” with the rise ot a materialistic theory ot the universe and a utilitarian theory ol morals. At present, the mechanical explanation oi nature under the form of the evolution hypothesis is again struggling lor the mastery.

The atom oi modern science is the atom of Lucretius without the power of swerving. But Lucretius ha'd no proper concep· tion of force. Here at once his physical theory breaks down. For the doctrine of attraction he had only the poor substitute ol varied shapes of atoms to keep them in combination. Repulsion, indeed, he foreshadowed in the importance he attached to the rebounding of atoms and masses aiter impact: but without the assumption oi force this rebounding is inconceivable, because the atoms are considered absolutely hard, and hence must be inelastic. For the inherent downward tendency of atoms, mod· ern science substitutes vibratory motion; it agrees with Lucre- tius in supposing the movements of atoms to be inconceivably swiit, lt agrees with him also in believing that all the processes oi nature take place in accordance with certain laws of universal sway and invariable action.
